choices.text: I - C, II - A, III - B
I - B, II - C, III - A
I - B, II - A, III - C
I - C, II - B, III - A

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
MALFORMATIONS :-

  • Primary errors of morphogenesis
  • An intrinsically abnormal developmental process
  • The result of a single gene or chromosomal defect
  • Congenital heart defects, anencephaly (absence of part or all of the brain), spina bifida, cleft lip/palate.

DISRUPTIONS :-

  • Secondary destruction of an organ or body region that was previously normal in development
  • The classic example of a disruption :- Amniotic bands, denoting rupture of amnion with resultant formation of "bands" that encircle, compress, or attach to parts of the developing fetus
  • A variety of environmental agents may cause disruptions.
  • Not heritable, hence they are not associated with increased risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies.

DEFORMATIONS :-

  • An extrinsic disturbance of development rather than an intrinsic error of morphogenesis.
  • Occurs late in fetal life
  • Affecting approximately 2% of newborn infants
  • Localized or generalized compression of the growing fetus, leading to a variety of structural abnormalities.
  • An abnormal form of or position of the body caused by nondisruptive mechanical forces.
  • Examples:- clubfoot, congenital hip location, infantile mandibular asymmetry, craniofacial asymmetry
  • The most common underlying factor responsible for deformations is uterine constraint.
  • Weeks of gestation, rapid increase in the size of the fetus outpaces the growth of the uterus, and the relative amount of amniotic fluid (which normally acts as a cushion) decreases.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Grossly, the lungs of this patient floats in water
Infants of diabetic mothers have a higher risk of developing this condition
Amniotic fluid phospholipids give a good estimate

questions.text: A preterm infant having weight appropriate for age was given resuscitation after birth. A neonatologist could hear fine rales over both lungs. A chest radiograph revealed ground glass opacities. After few hours, cyanosis developed and worsened. An autopsy findings of lung showed the following microscopic features. Which of the following statement about this case is NOT true?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is NEONATAL RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (RDS), also known as HYALINE MEMBRANE DISEASE because of the deposition of a layer of hyaline proteinaceous material in the peripheral airspaces

  • The fundamental defect in RDS is pulmonary immaturity and deficiency of surfactant
  • Neonates with congenital deficiency of surfactant caused by mutations in the SFTPB or SFTPC genes(choice B)
  • Grossly:- the lungs are normal size, they are solid, airless, and reddish purple, similar to the colour of the liver, and they usually sink in water, indicating the relative absence of entrapped air. (Choice A)
  • Microscopically, The necrotic material becomes incorporated within eosinophilic hyaline membranes (shown in the image) lining the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. The membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with cell debris derived chiefly from necrotic type II pneumocytes.
  • When the infant dies early in the course of the disease, necrotic cellular debris can be seen in the terminal bronchioles and alveolar ducts.
  • Because pulmonary secretions are discharged into the amniotic fluid, analysis of amniotic fluid phospholipids provides a good estimate to find out the level of surfactant.

Key Takeaways:

  • Neonatal RDS: Caused by surfactant deficiency, leading to ground-glass opacities and fine rales.
  • Lung appearance: Grossly, lungs are solid, airless, and usually sink in water.
  • Genetic cause: Mutations in SFTPB or SFTPC genes can cause surfactant deficiency.
  • Risk factor: Infants of diabetic mothers are at higher risk for RDS.
  • Amniotic fluid phospholipids: Used to estimate surfactant levels.

choices.text: Seen in very low birth weight infants
Stool and serum samples of infants show higher levels of PAF levels

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about necrotizing enterocolitis?
questions.solution:
Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)

  • Clinical course à Bloody stools, abdominal distention, and development of circulatory collapse.
  • Abdominal radiographs à gas within the intestinal wall (pneumatosis intestinalis) (choice D)
  • Most common in premature infants, with the incidence of the disease being inversely proportional to the gestational age. It occurs in approximately 1 in 10 very-low-birth-weight infants (<1500 g) (choice A)
  • The pathogenesis
  • Prematurity + enteral feeding à postnatal insult (such as introduction of bacteria) à culminating in tissue destruction. Although
  • Important role of infectious agents in the pathogenesis of NEC (no single bacterial pathogen has been linked to the disease)
  • Large number of inflammatory mediators plays significant role
  • One particular mediator, platelet activating factor (PAF) à increases mucosal permeability by promoting enterocyte apoptosis and compromising intercellular tight junctions à adding "fuel to the fire."
  • Stool and serum levels of PAF à high (choice C)
  • Breakdown of mucosal barrier functions à transluminal migration of gut bacteria à vicious cycle of inflammation à mucosal necrosis à further bacterial entry à sepsis and shock

Key Takeaways:

  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Common in very-low-birth-weight infants, especially premature ones.
  • Key features: Symptoms include bloody stools, abdominal distention, and circulatory collapse. Pneumatosis intestinalis (gas in the intestinal wall) is visible on radiographs.
  • Pathogenesis: Caused by a combination of prematurity, enteral feeding, and bacterial exposure, with high PAF levels in stool and serum.

questions.text: All of the following are transplacental infections, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Parasitic (e.g., Toxoplasma, malaria) and viral infections and a few bacterial infections (i.e., Listeria, Treponema) gain access to the fetal bloodstream transplacentally via the chorionic villi.
    • Can occur at any time during gestation or at the time of delivery (hepatitis B and HIV) via maternal-to-fetal transfusion.
  • The clinical manifestations - highly variable
    • Parvovirus B19, which causes erythema infectiosum or "fifth disease of childhood" in immunocompetent older children, can infect 1% to 5% of seronegative (nonimmune) pregnant women, and the vast majority have a normal pregnancy outcome.
    • diagnostic viral inclusions can be seen in early erythroid progenitors in infected infants
  • Adverse pregnancy outcomes in intrauterine infections à spontaneous abortion (particularly in the second trimester), stillbirth, hydrops fetalis (see later), and congenital anemia.
  • The TORCH group of infections -fever, encephalitis, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, pneumonitis, myocarditis, hemolytic anemia, and vesicular or haemorrhagic skin lesions.

Key Takeaways: TORCHES refers to infections that can be transmitted from mother to fetus, causing congenital abnormalities. It includes:

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Other (e.g., malaria, syphilis, varicella)
  • Rubella
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Herpes simplex virus
  • Epstein-Barr virus
  • Syphilis

These infections can lead to symptoms like fever, encephalitis, and skin lesions in newborns.

questions.text: Which organism is responsible for early onset perinatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
• Perinatal sepsis can be grouped clinically:-
    • Early onset (within the first 7 days of life)
    • Late onset (from 7 days to 3 months).
  • Most cases of early-onset sepsis are acquired at or shortly before birth and tend to result in clinical signs and symptoms of pneumonia, sepsis, and occasionally meningitis within 4 or 5 days of life.
  • GROUP B STREPTOCOCCUS à most common cause of early-onset sepsis and early-onset bacterial meningitis.
  • Infections with Listeria and Candida have longer latent periods between the time of microorganism inoculation and the appearance of clinical symptoms and present as late-onset sepsis.

Key Takeaways: Group B streptococci is the most common cause of early-onset perinatal sepsis and bacterial meningitis.

choices.text: Administration of RhIg at 32 weeks of gestation and within 72 hours of delivery to The negative mother
Administration of RhIg at 28 weeks of gestation and within one week of delivery to The negative mother
Administration of RhIg at 25 weeks of gestation and within 72 hours of delivery to The negative mother
Administration of RhIg at 32 weeks of gestation and within one week of delivery to The negative mother

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct that reduces the risk of hemolytic disease of Rh positive newborn?
questions.solution:
The incidence of maternal Rh isoimmunization has decreased significantly since the use of Rhesus immune globulin (RhIg) containing anti-D antibodies.

  • Administration of RhIg at 28 weeks of gestation and within 72 hours of delivery to Rh-negative mothers significantly decreases the risk for hemolytic disease in Rh-positive neonates and subsequent pregnancies.

Key Takeaways: RhIg should be administered at 28 weeks of gestation and within 72 hours of delivery to Rh-negative mothers to reduce the risk of hemolytic disease in Rh-positive newborns.

questions.text: All are causes of non-immune hydrops, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Blood group incompatibility (such as Rh incompatibility or ABO incompatibility) results in immune hydrops, not non-immune hydrops. In Rh incompatibility, if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive, maternal antibodies (IgG) cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells, leading to hemolysis, anemia, and subsequent heart failure in the fetus. This immune reaction results in immune hydrops, which is characterized by fluid accumulation in fetal tissues due to severe anemia and increased cardiac workload.
  • Immune hydrops is mediated by maternal antibodies targeting fetal red blood cells and can lead to fetal death, stillbirth, or significant morbidity in the newborn.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • a) Homozygous alpha thalassemia:
    • Homozygous alpha thalassemia results from the deletion or mutation of both alpha-globin genes on each chromosome 16, leading to severe fetal anemia. This severe anemia causes cardiac failure in the fetus, which results in hydrops. The impaired production of hemoglobin (HbF) in the fetus leads to an excessive production of ineffective erythroblasts in the bone marrow (erythroblastosis), which can cause fluid buildup in the tissues and organs (hydrops). This is a classic non-immune cause of hydrops.
  • b) Turner syndrome:
    • Turner syndrome (45,X) is a chromosomal disorder where the fetus has only one X chromosome instead of two sex chromosomes. This syndrome can cause lymphatic malformations, cardiac defects (especially coarctation of the aorta), renal anomalies, and growth restriction, which can contribute to non-immune hydrops. The presence of these structural and functional defects can lead to fetal cardiovascular failure and the development of hydrops fetalis.
  • c) Cardiovascular defects:
    • Cardiovascular defects, both structural (such as congenital heart defects) and functional (such as arrhythmias), are important causes of non-immune hydrops. These defects can result in intrauterine cardiac failure, which leads to the accumulation of fluid in fetal tissues and cavities, resulting in hydrops. Hydrops occurs because the heart is unable to effectively pump blood, leading to congestive heart failure and impaired circulation of fluids. This can also cause pleural effusion, ascites, and pericardial effusion.

Key Takeaways:

  • Non-immune hydrops is caused by fetal anemia, chromosomal anomalies, and cardiovascular defects (e.g., homozygous alpha thalassemia, Turner syndrome, congenital heart defects).
  • Immune hydrops is caused by maternal antibodies (such as in Rh or ABO incompatibility) attacking fetal red blood cells, whereas non-immune hydrops is caused by fetal conditions like anemia, cardiovascular defects, or chromosomal anomalies.

choices.text: >1 microliter of Rh positive fetal red cells
> 1 millilitre of Rh positive fetal red cells
> 1 litre of Rh positive fetal red cells
> 1 Nano litre of Rh positive fetal red cells

questions.text: Hemolytic disease develops only when the mother has transplacental bleed
questions.solution:
Several factors influence the immune response to RhD positive fetal red cells that reach the maternal circulation.

  • Concurrent ABO incompatibility protects the mother against Rh immunization because the fetal red cells are promptly coated and removed from the maternal circulation by anti-A or anti-B IgM antibodies that do not cross the placenta.
  • The antibody response depends on the dose of immunizing antigen; hence, hemolytic disease develops only when the mother has experienced a significant transplacental bleed (>1 mL of Rh-positive fetal red cells)

Key Takeaways:

  • Hemolytic disease develops when the mother has a transplacental bleed of >1 millilitre of Rh-positive fetal red cells.
  • A significant dose of Rh-positive cells in the maternal circulation triggers an immune response and leads to Rh sensitization.
  • ABO incompatibility can protect the mother from Rh immunization by removing fetal cells from circulation before they trigger an immune response.

questions.text: All features are seen in case of fetal hydrops, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
In hydrops associated with fetal anemia,

  • Both the fetus and placenta are characteristically pale
  • The liver and spleen are enlarged from cardiac failure and congestion. Additionally,
  • The bone marrow demonstrates compensatory hyperplasia of erythroid precursors
  • Extramedullary hematopoiesis (choice A) is present in the liver, spleen, lymph nodes, and possibly other tissues such as the kidneys, lungs, and even the heart.
  • The increased hematopoietic activity accounts for the presence in the peripheral circulation of large numbers of immature red cells, including reticulocytes and erythroblasts (erythroblastosis fetalis). (Choice C)
  • The most serious threat in fetal hydrops is CNS damage, known as kernicterus. (choice b) the affected brain is enlarged and edematous.
  • Blood bilirubin level greater than 20 mg/dL in term infants; in premature infants this threshold may be considerably lower. à neural damageà induces kernicterus
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis is seen in necrotizing enterocolitis, not in fetal hydrops.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fetal hydrops associated with fetal anemia leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis and erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Kernicterus can occur due to high bilirubin levels, causing CNS damage.
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis.

choices.text: Failure to thrive and intellectual disability
Deficiency of galactose - 1 - phosphate uridyl transferase

questions.text: Choose the FALSE statement regarding galactosemia from the following:
questions.solution:
GALACTOSEMIA

  • Autosomal recessive disorder (choice A) of galactose metabolism resulting from accumulation of galactose1-phosphate in tissues.
  • 1 in 60,000 live-born infants.
  • Normally, lactose, the major carbohydrate of mammalian milk, is split into glucose and galactose in the intestinal microvilli by lactase. Galactose is then converted to glucose in several steps catalyzed by distinct enzymes.
  • Two variants of galactosemia
    1. Total lack of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) - the more common variant (choice D)
    2. Deficiency of galactokinase - The rare variant
  • Galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in many locations, including the liver, spleen, lens of the eye, kidneys, heart muscle, cerebral cortex, and erythrocytes.
  • Signs & symptoms :-
    • These infants fail to thrive almost from birth. (Choice B)
    • Vomiting & diarrhoea appear within a few days of milk ingestion.
    • Jaundice and hepatomegaly - during the first week of life
    • Cataracts develop within a few weeks
    • Intellectual disability - within the first 6 to 12 months of life (choice B)
    • Aminoaciduria - Accumulation of galactose and galactose1-phosphate in the kidney impairs amino acid transport
    • fulminant Escherichia coli septicaemia, possibly arising from depressed neutrophil bactericidal activity.
    • Hemolysis and coagulopathy
  • Diagnosis :-
    • Fluorometric assay of GALT enzyme activity on a dried blood spot.
    • A positive screening test must be confirmed by assay of GALT levels in red cells.
    • Antenatal diagnosis is possible by assay of GALT activity in cultured amniotic fluid cells or determination of galactitol level in amniotic fluid supernatant

Key Takeaways: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. Symptoms include failure to thrive, intellectual disability, and cataracts

choices.text: Most SIDS infants die at home, during night after a period of sleep

questions.text: False about sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) :
questions.solution:
Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)

  • Approximately 90% of all SIDS deaths occur during the First 6 months of life, most between 2 and 4 months of age.
  • Most infants who die of SIDS die at home, usually during the night after a period of sleep. (Choice A)
  • the most compelling hypothesis is that SIDS reflects a delayed development of "arousal" and cardiorespiratory control.(choice D)
  • Multiple petechiae are the most common finding (~80% of cases); these are usually present on the thymus, visceral and parietal pleura, and epicardium

Key Takeaways: SIDS usually occurs in infants aged 2-4 months, often during sleep at home. It is linked to delayed arousal and cardiorespiratory control, with petechiae commonly found in the thymus, pleura, and epicardium. Maternal age over 35 is not a significant risk factor.

choices.text: Absence of schwannian stroma & gangliohistiocytic differentiation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a favourable prognostic factor in Neuroblastoma?
questions.solution:
Loss of chromosome 1p is considered an unfavourable prognostic factor in neuroblastoma. Chromosomal abnormalities, especially 1p deletions, are associated with poor survival and more aggressive forms of the disease. Favourable prognostic factors include younger age (less than 18 months), which is associated with better outcomes, and the presence of schwannian stroma and gangliohistiocytic differentiation, which indicate a less aggressive tumor.

Why the other options are Incorrect:

  • A) Age less than 18 months: Younger age at diagnosis is a favourable factor. Infants under 18 months tend to have better survival rates, as the tumor may regress spontaneously and is less likely to be aggressive.
  • B) Absence of schwannian stroma & gangliohistiocytic differentiation: The presence of schwannian stroma and gangliohistiocytic differentiation is a favourable factor, as it indicates a less aggressive, more differentiated tumor that is more likely to respond to treatment and have a better prognosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Favourable Prognosis: Age less than 18 months, presence of schwannian stroma, and gangliohistiocytic differentiation.
  • Unfavourable Prognosis: Loss of chromosome 1p.

questions.text: 14 months old patient with large abdominal mass shows the following microscopic image. Patient had breathing problems and bone pain. Laboratory tests reveals higher levels of vanillylmandelic acid and homovanilic acid. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ADRENAL NEUROBLASTOMA. This tumor is composed of small cells embedded in a finely fibrillar matrix (neuropil). Several Homer Wright pseudorosettes are seen in this image
  • The term neuroblastic tumor includes tumors of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla that are derived from primordial neural crest cells
  • Elevated blood levels of catecholamines and elevated urine levels of the metabolites vanillylmandelic acid [VMA] and homovanillic acid [HVA]) à important diagnostic feature.

Key Takeaways: Neuroblastoma is a tumor from neural crest cells, often in the adrenal glands. Elevated VMA and HVA levels, along with Homer Wright pseudorosettes in the tissue, confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Most common sites for Neuroblastoma to arise and metastasize respectively:
questions.solution:
• In childhood, neuroblastomas arise in the ADRENAL MEDULLA (40%) > paravertebral Region of the abdomen (25%) and posterior Mediastinum (15%).
  • Tumors may arise in numerous other sites, including the pelvis, the neck, and within the brain (cerebral neuroblastomas).
  • Neuroblastomas may metastasize widely through the hematogenous and lymphatic systems, particularly to liver, lungs, bones, and bone marrow.

Key Takeaways: Neuroblastomas most commonly arise in the adrenal medulla and metastasize to the liver.

questions.text: In the following microscopic image of Wilm's tumor, which component is not shown?
questions.solution:
The classic triphasic combination of Wilm's tumor:- BLASTEMAL, STROMAL, AND EPITHELIAL cell types.

  • Sheets of small blue cells with few distinctive features characterize the blastemal component.
  • Epithelial differentiation:- In the form of abortive tubules or glomeruli.
  • Stromal cells are usually fibroblastic or myxoid in nature, skeletal muscle differentiation.
  • Heterologous elements :- Squamous or mucinous epithelium, smooth muscle, adipose tissue, cartilage, and osteoid and neurogenic tissue.
  • The image shows :- Tightly packed blue cells (blastemal component) and interspersed primitive tubules (epithelial component). Multiple mitotic figures are seen. But stromal component is not shown in this image.

Key Takeaways:

To identify Wilm's tumor components:

  1. Blastemal: Small, blue, undifferentiated cells with high mitotic activity.
  2. Epithelial: Forms abortive tubules or glomeruli.
  3. Stromal: Fibroblastic or myxoid cells, may include muscle, cartilage, or fat.
